dataset.title: The effects of the invasive weed Arundo donax on insect biodiversity in the Kruger National Park

abstract.para: Arundo donax is an invasive weed which was recently discovered on the Sabie River in Kruger National Park and like many invasives it is thought to reduce biodiversity in its invaded environment. In this experiment we looked at the effects of the invasive weed on insect biodiversity in a riparian environment. We compared the species richness of A. donax to the native reed, Phragmites mauritianus and to a mixed vegetation environment. We found that A. donax did not significantly decrease the number of individuals or number of species found in pitfall traps. Biological diversity indices showed, however, that there was in fact a higher diversity in the A. donax insect populations. We also took measurements of the insect diversity of the three vegetation types by beating the reeds and analyzing the insects that fell out. We found a lower species richness in A. donax than in P. mauritianus. This can be explained by the fact that one species of ant is dominating P. mauritianus on the ground but dominating A. donax in the upper layers of the reed. This, in turn, says that the dominating species is pushing out other species accounting for a lowered diversity that might otherwise be found. In our study, A. donax did not significantly affect the biodiversity of insects overall found on P mauritianus within a riparian ecosystem.

keywordSet.keyword: Arundo donax, biodiversity, invasive species, alien species, Phragmites mauritianus,

section.title: methods
section.para: In order to determine the effects of invasion by A. donax on insect biodiversity, we conducted a study on the Sabie River (24. 97978 0S, 31. 48186 0 E) in Kruger National Park, Mpumalanga Province, South Africa, on 10 October 2005. We laid pitfall traps to assess insect abundance within three different sites, viz. stands of the native reed, Phragmites mauritianus, stands of the invasive reed Arundo donax as well as mixed stands of the two reed types. We chose two sites of the native, P. mauritianus, big enough to sufficiently cover a 2m by 2m matrix of pitfall traps, two sites of the invasive reed, A. donax and two sites of mixed vegetation. 2 different sized pitfall traps were used- the larger pitfall traps were 10 cm in diameter and 10 cm in depth, and the smaller traps were 4 cm in diameter and 5 cm deep. At each site, we laid nine pitfall traps in a 2m by 2m matrix, with alternating sized traps 1m apart. (Figure 1) Each vegetation type had one of each matrix type shown in Figure 1 A and B. This gave us 4 small and 5 big traps at one site and 5 small and 4 big at the other site for each vegetation type. Once all the traps were laid, we filled them each ¼ of the way full with anti-freeze to kill any insects that fell into the trap that could possibly climb or fly out.

Insects were collected 2 days later from the traps, and were identified by morphospecies back at the laboratory. On the same day that the pitfall traps were cleared, in order to collect another type of data, we collected insects from all 3 vegetation types by beating the vegetation. We placed a round tray with a 50cm diameter on the ground and repeatedly beat the vegetation with a 1 meter stick for 20 seconds. We then placed all the insects that fell out of the reeds onto the tray into vials and labelled them. This was repeated 10 times at each vegetation type (A. donax, mixed vegetation and P.mauritianus). These individuals were also taken back to the lab and identified to morphospecies.

In order to determine whether the diversity of insects was significantly different in the three sites, data for the number of individuals per trap, and the number of species per trap were analysed using Kruskal-Wallis, multiple comparison of means tests. (Statistica version. 6) When certain values were not considered significant we then did a post-hoc test to determine which, if any, of the relationships were significant. Similarities or differences in the insect communities were then determined using Primer to do a Multi Dimensional Scaling (MDS) plot, a similarity matrix and a biodiversity index for the number of individuals and species we collected in each trap. Next, we used Stastica again to do a Kruskal-Wallis test on the number of individuals collected per beating and the number of species per beating. Primer was then used to calculate a similarity matrix and a biodiversity index for the beating samples

attribute.attributeLabel: which 2x2 meter grid the trap was found in (right is trap closer to river, left is farther from river)
attribute.attributeDefinition: which 2x2 meter grid the trap was found in (right is trap closer to river, left is farther from river)
whether pitfal trap was big or small (big is yogurt container, small is insect vials)

position, means the location of the pitfall trap within a grid. This means that when looking at the grid with your back to the river, ABC were down the left side and 123 were across the top thus giving each position A1, A2, A3, B1,...etc)
species is the letter given to represent a morpho species. for example: large black beetles were called species G.
Number of individuals is the number found of that species in that specific trap.
overall position is the summary of the first four columns (for example PRS1 means Phragmites, Right side, Small trap, first trap within that grid.
number of individuals of that morpho-species found in that vegetation type by beating.
